node.title: Over 300 dogs found dead in Ukrainian shelter after weeks without food or water
node.description: Disturbing footage appeared showed dead dogs on the floor of the shelter.
node.content: ["CBS News warns our readers that this article contains  disturbing material.", "As new reports of atrocities\u00a0emerge in Ukraine and President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has accused Russia of genocide, disturbing footage has emerged on social media that appears to show dead dogs at an animal shelter in Borodyanka, Ukraine.\u00a0", "According to the charity UAnimals, the shelter's 485 dogs remained locked in their cages from the beginning of the war until the beginning of April, after Russian soldiers left Borodyanka and charity volunteers were able to access the shelter. During that time, the dogs were left there without any food or water, the charity said. By the time charity volunteers finally gained access to the building on April 1, all but 150 of the 485 animals had died of starvation or thirst.", "Oleksandra Matviichuk, head of the Center for Civil Liberties, tweeted a video in which the bodies of dozens of emaciated dogs can be seen piled on top of each other along the floor. The female volunteer filming the video narrates the scene through tears.\u00a0", "I have no words. Russians even killed dozens of dogs in Kyiv region. WHY??#RussiansWarCrimes pic.twitter.com/tvotxGUThs", "Ukrainian Interior Ministry advisor Anton Gerashchenko posted a separate video from the Borodyanka shelter on Telegram, in which dogs can be seen barking at volunteers as they step around the bloodied carcass of a dog who had died.\u00a0", "According to UAnimals, volunteers have now fed the dogs that survived and transferred the 27 animals in gravest condition to private clinics for treatment. And while volunteers have thus far only been able to pick up what UAnimals describes as the heaviest surviving dogs, the charity is offering 50,000 hryvnias \u2014 approximately $1,700 \u2014 as a reward for anyone willing and able to rescue the others.", "Christina Capatides is CBS News' Vice President of Social Media and Trending Content. She is also a senior producer and reporter, focusing on culture and gender equity."]
